close_symbols: i (local loop counter, declared as size_t)
buffer_head (char *) and the memory it indexes (connection->read_buffer)
MHD_strx_to_uint64_n_ (parses chunk-size, sets num_dig and chunk_size)
transmit_error_response_static / transmit_error_response_len (error path called adjacent to loops)
Any functions/macros that could be invoked from inside a for-loop body (none appear in the loop bodies here; list would be empty unless project-specific macros expand to function calls)
explanation:
To determine whether the for statements in process_request_body conform to the MISRA rule about well-formed for loops you must inspect (a) the loop counters themselves, (b) all objects used in the loop conditional and increment expressions, and (c) any functions or macros that could be executed inside the loop body (their behaviour counts as part of the loop body). The items above are required for that analysis for the following reasons:

- i (local loop counter, declared as size_t): The rule focuses on the loop counter. You must know the exact loop counter identifier and its declaration (type and scope) to check whether it is the single counter, whether it is initialized in the first clause, and whether it is modified only in the third clause and not elsewhere in the loop body.

- num_dig (size_t): num_dig is used to initialize/set i in one for and influences the initial value used by the nested for (the nested for uses ++i). You must know its value origin and type to assess whether the first-clause of the nested for meets MISRA requirements.

- available (size_t): available is used in the for-loop condition (i < available). MISRA forbids using objects in the condition that are also modified in the loop body (unless they are the loop counter or permitted loop control flags). You must be able to determine whether available is modified in the loop body (directly or indirectly via called functions/macros).

- buffer_head (char *) and the memory it indexes (connection->read_buffer): The loop bodies index buffer_head[i]. You must ensure that indexing does not invoke side effects that modify the loop counter or 'available'. Also if buffer_head points into memory that might be modified by a function called inside the loop body, that could affect loop control analysis.

- bare_lf_as_crlf and macro MHD_ALLOW_BARE_LF_AS_CRLF_: The boolean bare_lf_as_crlf appears in code paths that affect whether certain loop terminations are accepted. Understanding how the macro computes that value (and whether it has side effects) is necessary to reason about the loop conditions and whether any control flags are changed.

- allow_bws (bool): Used in branch logic that affects the for loops (which characters are skipped). Must ensure it is not modified in the loop body.

- size_t, uint64_t, bool (types): MISRA analysis needs the exact types of loop counters and related variables to reason about allowed operations, overflow, and whether counter modifications conform to the rule (e.g., only the loop counter is modified in the body).

- MHD_strx_to_uint64_n_: This function computes num_dig (and chunk_size). Because num_dig sets up the subsequent for loop(s), you need its behaviour to ensure the loops' first clauses initialize/set counters correctly and that reading num_dig does not introduce side effects that would violate the rule.

- mhd_assert (macro/function): Although not present inside the shown loop bodies, assertions can be implemented as macros that evaluate expressions or call functions; such expansions could introduce side effects (modifying variables used in loop clauses). You must know how mhd_assert expands/behaves to rule out side effects inside or adjacent to the loops.

- transmit_error_response_static / transmit_error_response_len: These functions are invoked on error paths closely associated with the chunk-parsing logic. While they are not inside the for-loop bodies shown, their presence in adjacent branches matters when reasoning about whether the code relies on side-effecting calls that might affect loop variables in ways relevant to MISRA analysis.

- memmove: Called after the loops to compact the buffer. The analysis must ensure that no aliasing or side effects of prior operations (including loop operations) violate the rule (and to confirm that the loops do not rely on external state changed by memmove).

- Any functions/macros that could be invoked from inside a for-loop body: MISRA requires that the behaviour of the loop body includes the behaviour of any called functions. In these particular for bodies there are no explicit function calls, but project-specific macros or inlined functions could expand into calls with side effects. You must be able to inspect those to ensure they do not modify the loop counter or other objects used in the loop condition/increment.

Provide these symbols/definitions (type declarations, macro definitions, and implementations or prototypes of the listed functions/macros) to the next analyst so they can verify whether each for statement meets MISRA's three-clause and single-counter constraints and whether any called code introduces forbidden side effects.
